<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 100, 225, 123]]<|/det|> Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 140, 116, 152]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 185, 100, 197]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 179, 272, 219]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 235, 598, 251]]<|/det|> ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS 0606/23 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 256, 92, 268]]<|/det|> Paper 2 May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[496, 278, 530, 290]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 302, 233, 316]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 327, 218, 340]]<|/det|> No additional materials are needed. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 353, 131, 365]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 367, 172, 379]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 380, 461, 394]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 395, 481, 409]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 422, 340, 435]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 436, 284, 448]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 450, 208, 463]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 464, 328, 478]]<|/det|> - You should use a scientific calculator where appropriate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 479, 272, 492]]<|/det|> - You must show all necessary working clearly. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 494, 508, 507]]<|/det|> - Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 520, 288, 532]]<|/det|> - For \(\pi\), use either your calculator value or 3.142. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 557, 131, 568]]<|/det|> INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 571, 231, 584]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 80 . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 586, 435, 600]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[46, 89, 288, 103]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \(\left(x-a\right)^{2}+\left(y-b\right)^{2}=r^{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 128, 338, 142]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A=\pi r l\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 168, 206, 182]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A=4 \pi r^{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 205, 338, 228]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V=\frac{1}{3} A h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 243, 207, 260]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V=\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 286, 146, 300]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(a x^{2}+b x+c=0\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[238, 302, 358, 331]]<|/det|>
\[
x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 378, 146, 392]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem \(\left(a+b\right)^{n}=a^{n}+\binom{n}{1} a^{n-1} b+\binom{n}{2} a^{n-2} b^{2}+\ldots+\binom{n}{r} a^{n-r} b^{r}+\ldots+b^{n}\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[238, 409, 465, 445]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r}=\frac{n !}{(n-r) ! r !}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 469, 131, 483]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n}=a+(n-1) d\) \(S_{n}=\frac{1}{2} n(a+l)=\frac{1}{2} n\{2 a+(n-1) d\}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 529, 131, 543]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n}=a r^{n-1}\) \(S_{n}=\frac{a(1-r^{n})}{1-r} \quad(r \neq 1)\) \(S_{\infty}=\frac{a}{1-r} \quad(|r|<1)\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[238, 623, 330, 639]]<|/det|>
\(\sin ^{2} A+\cos ^{2} A=1\) \(\sec ^{2} A=1+\tan ^{2} A\) \(\operatorname{cosec}^{2} A=1+\cot ^{2} A\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 676, 141, 690]]<|/det|>
Identities \(\begin{aligned}& \sin ^{2} A+\cos ^{2} A=1 \\& \sec ^{2} A=1+\tan ^{2} A \\& \operatorname{cosec}^{2} A=1+\cot ^{2} A\end{aligned}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[48, 725, 147, 740]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta A B C\) \(\begin{aligned}& \frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}=\frac{c}{\sin C} \\& a^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c \cos A \\& \Delta=\frac{1}{2} a b \sin C\end{aligned}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[579, 810, 598, 825]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[47, 64, 264, 78]]<|/det|>
1 Solve the inequality \((x+2)(4 x-5) \leqslant 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[47, 209, 402, 243]]<|/det|>
2 Given that \(y=\frac{4 x^{3}-5}{x^{2}}\), show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}\) can be written as \(\frac{2\left(2 x^{3}+5\right)}{x^{3}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[47, 492, 547, 508]]<|/det|>
3 Variables \(x\) and \(y\) are such that when \(\sqrt{y}\) is plotted against \(x^{3}\) a straight line graph passing through the points \((2,5)\) and \((10,21)\) is obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 531, 165, 545]]<|/det|>
Find \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[47, 64, 327, 77]]<|/det|>
4 The function f is defined by \(\mathrm{f}(x)=2 x-1\) for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 89, 297, 103]]<|/det|>
（a）Explain why the function \(\mathrm{f}^{2}\) can be formed．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 204, 307, 222]]<|/det|>
（b）On the axes，sketch the graph of \(y=\left|\mathrm{f}^{2}(x)\right|\) ． State any intercepts with the coordinate axes．

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 247, 421, 488]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 580, 461, 599]]<|/det|>
（c）It is given that \(\left|\mathrm{f}^{2}(x)\right| \leqslant a x+b\) for \(-1 \leqslant x \leqslant 3\) and for no other values of \(x\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 609, 218, 623]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[47, 62, 261, 77]]<|/det|>
5 In this question，all angles are in radians．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 83, 271, 109]]<|/det|>
（a）Write down the period of \(5 \tan \left(\frac{x}{4}\right)+1\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 225, 422, 251]]<|/det|>
（b）On the axes，sketch the graph of \(y=5 \tan \left(\frac{x}{4}\right)+1\) for \(-2 \pi \leqslant x \leqslant 4 \pi\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 258, 251, 272]]<|/det|>
State the intercept with the \(y\)－axis． Show clearly the positions of any asymptotes．

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 297, 480, 558]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[47, 62, 444, 77]]<|/det|>
6 (a) Five of the digits 123456789 are used to make a 5-digit number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 89, 490, 103]]<|/det|>
Find how many ways this can be done when the 5 -digit number is greater than 50000 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 258, 387, 272]]<|/det|>
(b) In a group of 13 people, 7 have red hair and 6 have brown hair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 284, 326, 298]]<|/det|>
(i) The 13 people stand in line for a photograph. No person with red hair is standing next to another person with red hair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 322, 356, 336]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways this can be done.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 492, 302, 506]]<|/det|>
(ii) Chris chooses 5 people from this group.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 518, 508, 531]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways Chris can do this if at least 1 person chosen has brown hair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[47, 64, 392, 100]]<|/det|>
7 (a) Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(x^{2}-\frac{3}{x^{4}}\right)^{15}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 252, 483, 271]]<|/det|>
(b) In the expansion of \((1+a x)^{9}\) the coefficient of \(x^{3}\) is 7 times the coefficient of \(x^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 281, 345, 296]]<|/det|>
Given that \(a\) is a positive constant, find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[47, 64, 243, 81]]<|/det|>
8 (a) It is given that \(y=\mathrm{e}^{3 x+2} \tan x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 93, 547, 107]]<|/det|>
Use calculus to find the approximate change in \(y\) as \(x\) increases from 0.1 to \(0.1+h\), where \(h\) is small.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 64, 271, 90]]<|/det|>
(b) A curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}=\sin (3 x+\pi)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 102, 292, 132]]<|/det|>
The curve passes through the point \(\left(\frac{\pi}{9}, \frac{4}{3}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 145, 409, 167]]<|/det|>
Find the exact \(y\)-coordinate of the point on the curve where \(x=\frac{5 \pi}{12}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[47, 62, 308, 77]]<|/det|>
9 (a) The 1st term of an arithmetic progression is 9. The last term of this progression is 159 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 89, 248, 101]]<|/det|>
The sum of all the terms is 2604 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 115, 491, 128]]<|/det|>
The 12th term of this arithmetic progression is the 1st term of a geometric progression. The 8th term of this arithmetic progression is the 2nd term of the geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 153, 382, 167]]<|/det|>
Find the sum of the first 6 terms of the geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 62, 338, 77]]<|/det|>
(b) A different geometric progression has 1st term \(\sin \theta\). The common ratio of this progression is \(\cos \theta\) where \(45^{\circ} \leqslant \theta \leqslant 135^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 102, 340, 116]]<|/det|>
(i) Show that this progression has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 245, 414, 259]]<|/det|>
(ii) Show that this sum to infinity can be written as \(\operatorname{cosec} \theta+\cot \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 62, 235, 77]]<|/det|>
10 In this question, time is in seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 89, 427, 103]]<|/det|>
(a) At time \(t=0\), particle \(P\) starts from the point with position vector \(-30 \mathbf{j}\). \(P\) travels with speed \(58 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) in the direction \(20 \mathbf{i}+21 \mathbf{j}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 128, 271, 142]]<|/det|>
Find the position vector of \(P\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 335, 478, 350]]<|/det|>
(b) Also at time \(t=0\), particle \(Q\) starts from the point with position vector \(-10 \mathbf{i}+18 \mathbf{j}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 357, 501, 378]]<|/det|>
\(Q\) travels with speed \(75 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) at an angle \(\alpha\) above the positive \(x\)-axis, where \(\tan \alpha=\frac{7}{24}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 388, 272, 402]]<|/det|>
Find the position vector of \(Q\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 62, 261, 77]]<|/det|>
(c) Determine whether \(P\) and \(Q\) collide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[47, 271, 412, 302]]<|/det|>
11 Given that \(\frac{{ }^{n+1} \mathrm{P}_{5}}{437}={ }^{n} \mathrm{P}_{3}\), use an algebraic method to find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[49, 64, 547, 81]]<|/det|>
12 The function f is defined by \(\mathrm{f}(x)=15 \cos ^{2}(3 x+1.5)+7 \sin (3 x+1.5)-13\) for \(-0.3 \leqslant x \leqslant 0.5\), where \(x\) is in radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 106, 228, 120]]<|/det|>
(a) Solve the equation \(\mathrm{f}(x)=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[71, 62, 438, 77]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the \(x\)-coordinates of the two stationary points on the curve \(y=\mathrm{f}(x)\).
